In the present case since the goods were covered by a specific heading i.e. Heading 25.01, the same cannot be classified under the residuary heading at all. This position is clearly laid down in Rule 3(a) of the Interpretative Rules set out above. As per the said Interpretative Rule 3(a), the heading which provides the most specific description shall be pref erred to the heading providing a more general description. This position is also well settled by a number of judgments of this Court. Reference may be made to Bharat Forge and Press Industries (P) Ltd. v. CCE11 . It was observed in para 4 inter alia as under: (SCC p. 534) '4. The question before us is whether the Department is right in claiming that the items in question are dutiable under Tariff Entry 68. This, as mentioned already, is the residuary entry and only such goods as cannot be brought under the various specific entries in the tariff should be attempted to be brought under the residuary entry. In other words, unless the Department can establish that the goods in question can by no conceivable process of reasoning be brought under any of the tariff items, resort cannot be had to the residuary item.' " ( emphasis in original) 58. In our opinion "yeast" is a chemical within the meaning of the entry in question. 59. For the views we have taken, it is not necessary for us to consider the other contentions raised by the parties. 60. For the reasons abovementioned, the impugned judgment cannot be sustained which is accordingly set aside. The appeals are allowed with costs. Counsel's fee assessed at Rs 50,000 (Rupees fifty thousand only). (2008) 5 Supreme Court Cases 697 (BEFORE S.B. SINHA AND DALVEER BHANDARI, JJ.) DINESH BORTHAKUR Versus Appellant; STATE OF ASSAM Respondent. Criminal Appeal No. 687 of 2007t, decided on March 13, 2008 A. Criminal Trial - Circumstantial evidence - Guilt not established - Flaw in investigation/prosecution - No incriminating materials - Without any material records, presumption of administration of poison and strangulation of MA (wife) and MU (daughter) by the appellant (accused) drawn - No record/investigation regarding purchase of pesticide or fingerprint of appellant on the used bottle or glass - No incriminating evidence on record linking the appellant regarding administration of 11 (1990) 1 sec 532: 1990 sec (Tax) 166 t From the Final Judgment and Order dated 26-4-2006 of the Gauhati High Court, Gauhati in Crl. Ltd.~cccc® IONLINEf True Prinf 698 SUPREME COURT CASES c2008) 5 sec poison/pesticide - Setting aside the conviction, held, existence of material ought to have been found before presuming any guilt - Moreover, no evidence of any mark of struggle by and between the two deceased with the a accused - Also, no motive for the crime identified - Besides, scraping of nails taken from the two deceased did not correspond to the scraping of skin taken from the body of the appellant - Appellant, therefore, entitled to acquittal - Appreciation of evidence - Prosecution - Penal Code, 1860, S.302 B. Criminal Trial - Circumstantial evidence - Last seen together - No evidence brought on record - Improper and ineffective investigation b and prosecution - Accused remained away from home from 11.30 a.m. to 4/5 p.m. - No evidence regarding appellant's working hours, opinion of co- workers, distance between office and home and mode of conveyance, etc. - No evidence to arrive at the presumption that appellant might have committed the murder during the time-lag between appellant's calling PW 1 for the first time and second time - Neighbours of the appellant were also not aware of any abnormality or incident before the appellant reached his c residence (i.e. the scene of crime) - If the theory that the appellant could have committed the crime within a couple of minutes is ruled out, held, no suspicion can be raised that the appellant had committed the crime The appellant was convicted of murder of his wife and adopted daughter by poisoning and strangulation. The trial court convicted the appellant on the basis that the reaction of the accused was not natural as he did not exhibit his emotion d or sadness despite the fact that a shocking incident had occurred and that the sniffer dog stayed near the accused. Allowing the appeal, the Supreme Court Held: The circumstantial evidence leading to the guilt of the appellant not having been established by the prosecution, the judgment of the conviction cannot be sustained. The prosecution made an attempt to show that the deaths of the e victims were caused by administration of poison and/or strangulation. The prosecution in a case of commission of murder by poisoning must bring in record some evidence linking the accused therewith. The bottle containing pesticide was found in the washbasin along with a glass inside the house. There is nothing on record to show that the appellant had purchased pesticide or brought it home. No fingerprint of the appellant was taken to show that it was he f who had used the bottle or the glass for the said purpose. No incriminating evidence linking the appellant in regard to administration of poison/pesticide has been brought on record. A finding of guilt cannot be based on a presumption. Before arriving at an inference that the appellant has committed an offence, existence of materials therefor ought to have been found. (Paras 60, 54, 56 and 33) Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra, (1984) 4 SCC 116 : 1984 SCC (Cri) g 487, relied on The prosecution did not bring on record any material to show that the deceased had put up any resistance when the appellant had allegedly tried to commit the crime. There was no evidence of any mark of struggle by and between the two deceased with the accused. PW 6, in his evidence, in no uncertain terms, admitted that the scraping of nails taken from the two deceased h did not correspond to the scraping of skin taken from the body of the appellant. (Paras 37 and 30) ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. STATE OF ASSAM 699 If the theory that he could have committed the murder within a couple of minutes is ruled out, no suspicion can be raised that the appellant had committed the crime. It is not the case of the prosecution that the deceased were last seen in the company of the appellant. Nobody had seen him going inside his house or coming out at the time of or nearabout the commission of the crime. The matter might have been different if some evidence had been introduced to suggest that the offence was committed sometime between 11.30 a.m. and 4/5 p.m. and to infer that he could forcibly administer poison to the deceased or strangulate them or to do the both so as to cause their deaths. (Paras 48 and 30) The time-lag between the appellant's calling PW 1 for the first time and the second time was a few minutes. The prosecution did not suggest nor any finding has been arrived at that the offence could have been committed during the said interval. (Paras 35, 34 and 41) C. Criminal Procedure Code, 1973 - S. 154 - FIR - Delay in filing FIR - Indirect information to police prior to FIR - Effect - FIR was lodged by appellant-accused only when police arrived at the scene of occurrence - PW 1 (neighbour of appellant) getting information from appellant had informed the police - Held, there is no delay on the part of appellant in informing the police (Paras 58 and 5) D. Criminal Trial - Appreciation of evidence - Presumption of adverse inference as to guilt - Incorrect basis - The fact of delay in informing police (lodging FIR) was misconstrued - PW 1 (neighbour of appellant) getting information from appellant had informed the police - On facts, held, no presumption of adverse inference can be raised against the appellant- Criminal Procedure Code, 1973 - S. 154-FIR (Paras 58 and 27) E. Criminal Trial - Dog tracking - Evidence of sniffer dog - Held, inadmissible - Sniffer dog going near the appellant was one of the major grounds of conviction - Held, improper F. Criminal Trial - Identification - Utility of sniffer dog - Identification by sniffer dog, held, is only for purpose of investigation and not for evidence - Criminal Procedure Code, 1973, S. 156 The services of a sniffer dog may be taken for the purpose of investigation. Its faculties cannot be taken as evidence for the purpose of establishing the guilt of an accused. One of the grounds of conviction was that the sniffer dog had gone near the appellant only and nobody else when he had been inside the house. The evidence of PW 6, PW 8, PW 9 and PW 13 who testified about the sniffer dog's staying near the accused was wrongly relied on. (Paras 40, 27 and 38) Abdul Rajak Mu,taja Dafedar v. State of Maharashtra, (1969) 2 SCC 234; Gade Lakshmi Mangaraju v. State of A.P., (2001) 6 SCC 205: 2001 SCC (Cri) 1082, relied on G. Criminal Trial -Appreciation of evidence - Conduct of accused - Court inferring the guilt and convicting the appellant-accused on the ground that he did not show any initial reaction on the discovery of murder/death of his wife and adopted daughter - Predefined reaction(s), held, is/are not determinable and resultant presumptions based on inferences, therefore, fallible - On facts, however, no abnormality found in the reaction of appellant - Penal Code, 1860, S. 302 - Evidence Act, 1872 - Ss. 114 and 8 - Common course of human - Presumptions as to conduct Merely because the appellant did not cry or weep on witnessing the dead bodies of his wife and daughter, cannot be made the basis for inferring his guilt. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. Ltd.~cccc® IONLINEf True Prinf 700 SUPREME COURT CASES c2oos) s sec Even if the conduct of the appellant demonstrated that he had been feeling sorry for the death of his daughter and not for his wife, it does not lead to any conclusion. The purported absence of any reaction on the part of the appellant in a regard to the death of the two deceased was for all intent and purpose made the sole basis for his conviction by the trial Judge. The conduct of the appellant, so far his initial reaction to the occurrence is concerned, appears to be most natural as he suspected that something was wrong but was unsure thereabout at the same time. In any view of the matter, it does not give rise to an inference which is consistent with the hypothesis of guilt. (Paras 4 7, 51, 31 and 36) An accused person's conduct or reaction (or lack of it) by itself, cannot be a b ground for arriving at a conclusion that he is guilty of commission of crime. Formation of another opinion is also possible. No hard-and-fast rule having any universal application with regard to the reaction of a person in a given circumstance can be laid down. One person may lose equilibrium and balance of mind, but, another may remain a silent spectator till he is able to reconcile himself and then react in his own way. (Paras 49 and 4 7) c Rana Partap v. State of Haryana, (1983) 3 SCC 327 : 1983 SCC (Cri) 601; Manvadi Kishor Pannanand v. State of Gujarat, (1994) 4 SCC 549: 1994 SCC (Cri) 1294; State of U.P. v. Devendra Singh, (2004) 10 SCC 616 : 2005 SCC (Cri) 582, relied on H. Criminal Trial - Appreciation of evidence - Irrelevant fact - Fact of spectacles of appellant-accused lying on a book of murdered/dead adopted daughter - Allegation of father murdering wife and adopted daughter by poisoning and strangulation - The said fact, held, is irrelevant d I. Criminal Trial - Appreciation of evidence - Process and mode of appreciation - Duty of trial court - When judicial notice of statements/facts is taken, the trial court, held, should draw inference regarding its relevancy J. Criminal Trial - Circumstantial evidence - Motive - No evidence of motive brought out by prosecution - On the contrary the appellant- e accused neither ran away from the scene of occurrence nor stayed back in the office waiting for the information from others - His conduct like calling the deceased (his wife) in loud voice, making queries from PW 1 and entering his house (scene of crime) through rear side, held, was normal - Therefore, no motive for murder was brought out which even the trial court accepted The trial Judge failed to analyse the evidence of the prosecution witnesses in f a proper and effective manner. Although opining that he had no motive to kill his wife and the adopted daughter, the effect thereof was not considered keeping in view the fact that the prosecution rested its case only on circumstantial evidence. How the links in the chain of the circumstances led to only one conclusion that the appellant and the appellant alone was guilty of commission of the offence has not been spelt out by the trial Judge. (Paras 29 and 33) g The trial Judge, although took notice of the statements of PW 13 that the spectacles of the appellant were found lying on a book of the murdered daughter, drew no inference therefrom. He also did not make any attempt to determine the relevance of the said evidence although the said evidence does not have any relevance to the prosecution case. (Para 29) No motive for committing the crime was identified. Ordinarily, an accused h person after commission of such a ghastly crime would run away from the scene ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. Even if he was to pretend that he did not know about the said occurrence, he could have stayed back in his office waiting for the call of his neighbours about the death of his wife and daughter. PW 1 and PW 2, in their deposition, did not notice any unusual conduct on the part of the appellant or the deceased wife on that day. There was no abnormality in the initial reaction of the appellant. He knocked at the door vigorously. He called the deceased in a loud voice which attracted the attention of PW 1. On a query made by the latter, he stated that they had not been opening the door and only when PW 1 opined that they must have been sleeping, he went to the rear side of the premises and discovered the dead bodies of his wife and daughter lying on the bed and again without any loss of time called PW 1. (Paras 33, 48, 42 and 44) K. Criminal Trial - Witnesses - Prosecution witness - Reliability of witness regarding irregular conduct of appellant-accused - Appellant- accused regularly going to pan shop of PW 10 and not going on the day of crime as per deposition of PW 10 - PW 10 admitted in his cross-examination that his brother used to sit in the pan shop in the forenoon - Evidence of PW 10, held, is not at all reliable (Para 59) L. Criminal Trial - Conviction - Presumption of murder - Doubtful basis - Doubt as to whether homicidal or suicidal - Medical evidence not clear - Expert who conducted the post-mortem examination not sure whether the death was suicidal or homicidal - Therefore, presumption as to murder (homicide), held, doubtful (Paras 37, 24 and 25) SS-M/A/37600/CR Advocates who appeared in this case : Ms Meenakshi Arora, Advocate, for the Appellant; Ms Momota and Ranjan Mazumdar (for Mis Corporate Law Group), Advocates, for the Respondent. Chronological list of cases cited on page(s) 1. (2004) 10 SCC 616 : 2005 SCC (Cri) 582, State of U.P. v. Devendra Singh 708c 2. (2001) 6 SCC 205: 2001 SCC (Cri) 1082, Gade Lakshmi Mangaraju v. State of A.P. 707a 3. (1994) 4 SCC 549 : 1994 SCC (Cri) 1294, Marwadi Kishor Parmanand v. State of Gujarat 708c-d 4. (1984) 4 SCC 116 : 1984 SCC (Cri) 487, Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra 709!, 710a, 710b 5. (1983) 3 SCC 327: 1983 SCC (Cri) 601, Rana Partap v. State of Haryana 708a 6. (1969) 2 SCC 234, Abdul Rajak Murtaja Dafedar v. State of Maharashtra 706g The Judgment of the Court was delivered by S.B. SINHA, J.- The appellant was convicted and sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for life on the charge of murder of his wife Mala Borthakur and adopted daughter Munni @ Mayuri. He was residing with the first deceased at Sibnath Bhattacharya Lane, Chiring Chapari in the town of Dibrugarh. 2. He is an Engineer by profession. At about 4.00/5.00 p.m. on 25-5-1999, when he returned from his place of work, he allegedly knocked the main door of the house. There was no response. He called his immediate neighbour Pranab Kumar Baruah (PW 1). ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. Ltd.~cccc® IONLINEf True Prinf 702 SUPREME COURT CASES (2008) 5 sec 3. PW 1, whose house is separated only by a wall, opened the window and asked him as to what had happened. To that the appellant allegedly replied "they are not opening the door". He responded thereto saying that a "they are perhaps sleeping". He went to the rear side of the premises. He found the same open. 4. He was heard shouting loudly calling the name of his daughter Munni and wife Mala several times. He found his wife and daughter lying dead on separate beds. After a few minutes, the appellant called PW 1 again shouting "Boruah! Boruah!". On his query as to what had happened, he asked him to b come and have a look. PW 1 found the wife of the deceased (sic appellant) lying on the bed with her face down. He also saw the lower part of her legs looking pale. His attention was also drawn by the appellant to the corpse of Munni. The leg of the girl was shaken by the appellant stating, "look, she is also not moving". The appellant remarked, "Mala should not have done this". 5. PW 1, thereafter, asked somebody (whose name has not been c disclosed) to inform the police. As the said request was not complied with, he himself informed the officer in charge of the police station about the incident. 6. For the purpose of investigation, a sniffer dog was brought into service. The dog was taken near the dead bodies. It allegedly went close to the appellant only and no one else when he was inside the house. 7. PW 1, in his deposition before the court opined "that even though such d a shocking incident had taken place, Borthakur did not show any reaction as he should have". He, however, in his cross-examination stated: "Having seen the occurrence, I had lost my senses. He too might have been out of his mind to some extent. Reactions vary with people. As the deceased were the accused person's wife and daughter respectively, his reaction should have been more acute. Reaction of the accused person e that I had noticed might have been for the unexpected turn of event. He was repeatedly going near the dead body of his daughter but not that of his wife." 8. Apart from PW 1, his wife Purnima Devi examined herself as PW 2. According to her, at about 10.10 a.m. when she had been going to her office, the daughter of the accused, Munni, had been crying. On being asked the f reason therefor, Mala had replied that Munni had been crying because she had been giving her a bath. 9. PW 3 Binu Bezborauah was also a neighbour of the appellant. She was also a witness to the unusual crying of the girl. 10. PW 4 Shri Manas Barpujari is an employee of the Education Department. He is the brother-in-law of the appellant. According to him, 9 when the appellant having been asked at around 3.30/4.00 p.m. as to what had happened, he replied "she killed Munni, she killed herself too". Reaction of PW 4 upon seeing the dead body, however, was that she had been murdered. He accepted that the marriage between the deceased Mala and the appellant took place 16-17 years prior to his date of deposition and, apparently they had good relations. According to him, he had not witnessed h any quarrel between them. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. Ltd.~cccc® IONLINEf True Prinf a b C d e f g h DINESH BORTHAKUR V. STATE OF ASSAM ( Sinha, J.) 703 11. PW 5, Dr. R. Chaliha conducted the post-mortem examination. 12. PW 6 is Rubul Sharmah. He allegedly had seen a skipping rope around the neck of Mala as also a gold chain. He also allegedly noticed blood dripping out from the corners of her lips. He also found black marks around the neck of Munni. 13. The investigating officer also found a bottle of poison. 14. According to PW 6, sheets of the bed on which the dead bodies were found, had been neatly spread. He also noticed arrival of the police dog. According to him, after having smelt the dead bodies, the dog did not go out of the room but stayed inside it near and about the appellant. 15. PW 7 Shri Dhiraj Sharmah, was a neighbour. He came to the place of occurrence. According to him, Manas Barpujari came crying and told him "Someone has killed Bubli baiden ( elder sister) and her daughter Munni and had left their dead bodies on the bed." 16. PW 8 is Shri Manik Barkakoty. He was only a witness in regard to the conduct and/or reaction of the appellant. Evidence of PW 9, Shri Chandan Sharmah, was confined to the scene of the bedrooms. 17. PW 10 Shri Bijoy Prasad is the owner of a pan shop. According to him the accused did not buy any pan from his shop on the date of incident i.e. 25-5-1999. 18. PW 11 Shri Ganesh Borthakur is the brother of the accused. He, having been informed, visited the place of occurrence. His evidence is not very material. 19. PW 12 is Smt Manjuri Borthakur. According to her, she found the accused sobbing and moving hither and thither in the room in which his daughter had been lying dead. 20. PW 13 Shri Anup Baruah was a resident of a place which was at a distance of four furlongs from the appellant's house. Somebody informed him about the said deaths whereupon he went there. 21. PW 14 Shri Anupma Dutta also deposed to the same effect. PW 15 Shri Samudra Baishya is a Chemical Engineer. According to him the bottle contained organophosphorus pesticide which is a kind of insecticide used in vegetable cultivations. 22. PW 16 Shri Kusheswar Baruah was the officer in charge of Lakhimpur Police Station. He is the investigating officer in the case. He admitted that PW 1 Pranab Baruah had not stated before him that "Mala should not have done this nor did he inform that the accused had frequently gone near his daughter but not near his wife". Similarly, PW 4 Manas Barpujari did not state before him about the alleged remark of the appellant that "deceased Mala had killed Munni and killed herself too and that he had seen scratch marks on the back of the appellant". PW 6 Rubul Sharmah did not inform him that he had seen blood coming out of Mala's mouth and that some milk like things had been found in the glass at the scene. Similarly, PW 9 Chandan Sharmah did not state before him that Mala and Munni had been found lying on the same bed. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. Only on the basis of the aforementioned materials brought on record by the prosecution, a judgment of conviction against the appellant was recorded by the learned trial judge. The High Court dismissed the appeal a pref erred thereagainst. 24. The fact that Munni suffered a homicidal death is not in dispute. However, there appears to be some dispute as to whether death of Mala was homicidal or suicidal in nature. The dead bodies of both Mala and Munni were having ligature marks but the doctor opined that only Munni died of asphyxia. No such opinion was rendered in respect of the death of Mala. b However, the result of the chemical examination showed presence of organophosphorus pesticide, a poison. 25. In regard to death of Mala, PW 5, in his deposition, stated: "Regarding Mala Borthakur, in my post-mortem report, I have not mentioned word 'homicide'. Report is/was silent about homicide .... C In the instant case, my opinion is/was silent regarding Mala Borthakur whether it was suicidal or homicidal." 26. What has been noticed hereinbefore clearly demonstrates that the prosecution led only circumstantial evidence before the learned trial Judge. The learned trial Judge, apart from the statements made by the prosecution witnesses in regard to the conduct of the appellant, also took into d consideration the fact that he had not informed the police in regard to the death of "his own wife and adopted daughter". It was furthermore opined that the appellant had failed to establish his own innocence. An adverse inference was drawn against the accused in regard to his failure to inform about the death of his wife and adopted daughter till the arrival of the police party to his house. e 27. The learned trial Judge also noticed that the sniffer dog had gone near the appellant only and nobody else when he had been inside the house. According to the learned trial Judge, the behaviour of the accused was abnormal as he had neither wept nor cried nor shown any sign of shock or being upset at the scene of death of "his own wife and adopted daughter". Emphasis was also laid on the fact that when the appellant was being f interrogated by the investigating officer, allegedly, he had told him that he was feeling hungry and had bought some food from a line hotel. 28. In his judgment, the learned trial Judge referred to the statements of the appellant in his examination under Section 313 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in great detail. Statement of PW 1 was also quoted in extenso. 29. The learned trial Judge, however, in our opinion, failed to analyse the 9 evidence of the prosecution witnesses in a proper and effective manner. Although opining that he had no motive to kill his wife and the adopted daughter, the effect thereof was not considered keeping in view the fact that the prosecution rested its case only on circumstantial evidence. The learned trial Judge, although took notice of the statements of PW 13 that the spectacles of the appellant were found lying on a book of Munni, drew no h inference therefrom. He also did not make any attempt to determine the ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. We, however, do not find the said evidence having any relevance to the prosecution case. The learned trial Judge furthermore placed on record that according to PW 13, marks of blood on the nails of the deceased having been noticed, the investigating officer got the shirt removed from the body of the appellant and found two nail marks on his back. 30. The learned trial Judge accepted that there was no evidence brought on record to show that the accused was seen at the place of the occurrence of crime during the period between 11.30 a.m. in the morning hours and at about 4.00/5.00 p.m. in the afternoon, so as to enable it to infer that he could forcibly administer poison to the deceased or strangulate them or to do the both so as to cause their deaths. He further recorded that PW 6 admitted in his evidence that the nail scraping taken from the two deceased did not correspond to the skin scraping taken from the body of the accused. Thus, there was no evidence of any mark of struggle by and between the two deceased with the accused. 31. The purported absence of any reaction on the part of the appellant in regard to the death of the two deceased was for all intent and purpose made the sole basis for his conviction by the learned trial Judge of the offence. It was concluded: "So, taking the gamut of all the circumstances analysed in paras 19, 24, 25, 31, 33, 37, 38, 43, 46, 47 and 54 above in particular and the case laws mentioned in para 55 above in entirety, I am very much persuaded to presume that it was the present accused Dinesh Borthakur, and none else who had intentionally caused the death of his wife Mala Borthakur and his adopted daughter in a cold-blooded manner to eliminate them from this earth with some motive best known to himself. The evidence on record of this instant case relating to circumstances and conduct of the accused sufficiently and clearly established all the links in the chain of circumstances leading to the guilt of the present accused and no reasonable ground was left for consideration consistent with his innocence." ( emphasis supplied) 32. The judgment of the High Court with respect is no different. 33. A finding of guilt cannot be based on a presumption. Before arriving at an inference that the appellant has committed an offence, existence of materials therefor ought to have been found. No motive for committing the crime was identified which, in the facts and circumstances of the case, was relevant. How the links in the chain of the circumstances led to only one conclusion that the appellant and the appellant alone was guilty of commission of the offence has not been spelt out by the learned trial Judge. 34. The courts below did not record any finding on the basis of any material brought on record by the prosecution that the appellant was seen at the place of occurrence of crime between 11.30 a.m. to 4/5 p.m. The least the prosecution, in this behalf, could do was to examine the co-employees of the appellant who had been working in his office to find out as to when he had ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v.
